Award.AwardTitle: Regulated sialylation modulates cardiac excitability and conduction
Award.AbstractNarration: Electrical signaling occurs in all cells and is of primary importance to excitable cell function. Neurons, skeletal and cardiac muscle communicate through production and conduction of electrical signals called action potentials (AP), a transient depolarization of the membrane produced by the concerted and highly regulated activities of many voltage-gated ion channels. Slight alterations in ion channel activity often lead to altered excitability. Some of the ion channel functions depend on sugar groups, called glycans, that may comprise ~15-30% of the mature ion channel mass. Most studies showed that sugar-dependent gating effects were imposed primarily by the terminal residue, sialic acid. However, little is known about whether and how regulated sialylation modulates excitability and conduction, in vivo. Thus, questioning whether and how (mechanistically) regulated sialylation modulates cardiac excitability and conduction will be investigated. A broad range of methods including molecular, cellular, tissue, whole animal, and computational techniques will be used at several organizational levels on an animal model comprised of 1) Sialyltransferase (ST) knockout strains producing proteins with fewer attached sialic acids, and 2) The enzymatic removal of sialic acids and N-glycans. The proposed studies are designed to test the viability of a novel mechanism by which glycans modulate electrical signaling, in vivo and in silico. The paradigm challenges being studied throughout this work and the melding of disparate biological areas including ion channel and glyco-biology, have broad implications. Because ion channel activity is involved in the function of all cells of the body, and since nearly all ion channels are glycosylated, gaining an understanding of a functional role for glycosylation in electrical signaling will likely have broad scientific impact. If the studies indicate that glycan structures influence ion channel function, then future studies should address the impact of glycans on ion channel structure as it relates to channel function. In addition to these broad scientific implications, the proposed studies will have broader impact that includes education, communication, and health. To address these broader issues, undergraduate, graduate, and medical students, particularly including minority students, will be trained in the scientific method by asking a fundamental question utilizing a variety of techniques. The generated scientific findings will be shared with the general scientific community, the lay public, and our collaborators, and effectively communicate the impact of these findings on the health of society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit - In addition to 51 peer-reviewed original reports, we published several books/chapters and presented our work at tens of national/international meetings with several winning best paper awards, all acknowledging support, at least in part, from this NSF award. Thus, we used biophysical and biochemical techniques at multiple levels comparing myocyte and cardiac excitability and conduction following deletion of the sialyltransferase gene, ST3Gal4, a model for reduced sialylation. These data were then used to develop and validate in-silico models of cardiac muscle electrical signaling. Examples of significant and novel contributions made during this award include the following: 1) Determined how functional changes at one level (e.g., ion channel) impact function at another level (e.g., myocyte, whole heart), 2) Showed that hERG channel (a voltage-gated potassium channel that is vital to human action potential repolarization) sialylation modulates channel gating. 3) Developed in-silico models showing hERG channel sialylation contributes directly to action potential waveform and cardiac conduction. 4) Demonstrated that ST3Gal4 expression modulates voltage-gated sodium channel and some voltage-gated potassium channel sialylation and gating, myocyte and ventricular refractory periods, action potential durations, and increases susceptibility to arrhythmias. 5) Developed electrical in-silico models describing the impact of sialic acids on voltage-gated ion channel gating and myocyte electrical signaling. 6) Developed a novel biochemical assay to determine relative sialic acid levels attached to specific voltage-gated ion channel isoforms. 7) Showed that voltage-gated sodium channel gating can be modulated by N- and O-linked sialic acids. 8) Developed a new statistical metamodeling approach for efficient optimization of cardiac models. 9) A whole-heart model based on modern general-purpose computing on graphics processing units architecture was developed. 10) Developed new reaction-diffusion methods/pattern recognition tools to model spatiotemporal dynamics of electrical wave conduction and propagation in the 3D whole heart. 11) Showed that ST3Gal4  knockout mice were also susceptible to stress-induced heart failure, suggesting a link between global changes in sialylation and electromechanical functions. 12) Very recent findings show that chronic reductions in complex N-glycosylation are sufficient to alter cardiac electrical signaling and contraction.

Broader Impacts -  We exceeded the broader impact aims of the NSF award through effective communication of our major findings and by providing excellent training opportunities for all involved, from K-12 students to the co-PI and PI. The most compelling evidence of our contributions in this area is the success of our Ph.D. student mentees during this award period, with three mentees now holding Assistant Professor positions at major research universities. Additional broader impacts achieved during the previous award include: 1) Several Ph.D. students within the groups received “Best student papers/posters at national and international meetings, 2) A postdoctoral scholar received an American Heart Association post-doctoral fellowship while under the mentorship of the PI, 3) Participation in educational activities such as UPWARD BOUND (USF), USF Engineering Exposition, and Stampede to Success, 4) Running sensing-simulation workshops for K-12 students and teachers that include lab sessions to actively practice, feel, and see experimental operations, 5) Mentoring high school students on a weekly basis, the majority of whom identified as under-represented minority students. Students were trained on various domains, including self-organizing network, simulation modeling, and Matlab programming, and 6) Receipt of an NSF I-Corps Project that provided commercialization training to several Ph.D. students.
